Key Arguments: The legislation lacks sufficient justification and evidence of the need for new powers to combat misinformation and disinformation.
Existing laws and regulations are adequate to address misinformation and disinformation.
The bill poses a threat to freedom of speech and democratic principles by potentially stifling dissenting viewpoints.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are circular and biased towards government-approved narratives.
The bill could lead to censorship and suppression of valid scientific discourse.
There are concerns about conflicts of interest, particularly with pharmaceutical companies influencing what is considered misinformation.
The bill could harm healthcare professionals' ability to provide accurate and transparent information to patients.
Notable Quotes: The onus should be on ACMA to sufficiently demonstrate that there is a problem.
The bill relies on a circular definition of misinformation and disinformation, whereby the official position is the ‘true’ one.

Censorship is inherently non-democratic; it aligns with the sentiment of German-American political philosopher Eric Voegelin who stated that it's 'the common feature of all totalitarian systems...the prohibition of questions.'
The solution and answer to bad/poor/wrong speech is MORE speech so that the truth will come out in the marketplace of ideas.
